Context:
Program Name: Baking and Pastry Foundations
Code: H128
Credential: Ontario College Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 1 year (2 semesters)
Starting Months: January
Domestic Tuition: $6,657.00 *
International Tuition: $20,540.00 **
Centre: Hospitality & Culinary Arts
School: Chef School
Location: St. James Campus
Program Description: Prepare for a baker or pastry chef career with the one-year Baking and Pastry Foundations certificate program. Students learn basics of pastry, cakes, decorating, artisanal bread, chocolate techniques, menu management, nutrition through hands-on training and classroom learning.
Career Options: large bakery production, hotel industry.
* Domestic tuition is for Canadian students, ** International tuition is for students from other countries.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Baking and Pastry Foundations Program H128 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about skills needed for a career in bakery production, hotel pastry departments, catering companies, and starting one's own business. To be eligible for certain programs at the Ontario college, one needs to graduate from a culinary or baking and pastry management program or possess one year of industry experience.

The Advanced French Patisserie postgraduate program (H413) and the Baking and Pastry Arts Management diploma program (H113) are mentioned as possible paths for graduates. The former is open to applicants with a culinary or baking and pastry management degree, while the latter may accept graduates directly into the second year based on space availability.

The following required courses are listed under Semesters 1 and 2:

Semester 1:
- HOSF1145: Sanitation
- HOSF1094: Baking and Pastry Arts Theory I
- HOSF1093: Baking and Pastry Arts Skills I
- HOSF1146: Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)
- COMM2000: Communicating Across Contexts*
- MATH1200: Culinary Math Essentials
- GSCI1035: Science of Sustainability

Semester 2:
- HOSF1287: WHMIS
- HOST1068: Smart Serve
- HOSF1097: Baking and Pastry Arts Theory II
- HOSF1096: Baking and Pastry Arts Skills II
- HOSF1224: Dessert Menu Management*
- HOSF2060: Baking and Pastry Production I*
- HOSF1255: Nutrition Fundamentals from a Culinary Perspective
- HOST1126: Career Preparation*
- HOSF1206: Cost Control* (hybrid)

(* Seven-week course)

The text also mentions that students may need to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000, depending on the results of their placement test. This extra course is not counted towards graduation and will incur additional charges. Students can visit the Assessment Centre for more information.

Program Learning Outcomes:
The graduate has reliably demonstrated the ability to identify:
- Various career paths within the bakery industry, including large bakeries, hotel pastry departments, catering companies, and entrepreneurship
- Eligibility requirements for postgraduate and diploma programs at the Ontario college
- Required courses for each semester in culinary arts and management
- The potential need for additional communication courses depending on placement test results.

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Graduate has reliably demonstrated the ability to identify ingredients' workings and effects on each other and predict end product.
- Perform problem-solving and troubleshoot recipes.
- Perform basic bakery techniques.
- Recognize and produce classical and modern baked goods.
- Apply food safety principles and practices.
- Apply mathematical principles and recipe conversions, bakery formulations, and percentages.
- Practice skills used in daily bakery operations, including cost controls, inventory management, etc.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (Fall 2023): $6,657.00
- International Tuition (Fall 2023): $20,540.00
- Additional Costs: Small wares ($100-$300), Manuals and books ($400)

Note: Semester 1 tuition fees include the cost of a baking kit, safety shoes, and Chef School uniform.

Financial Assistance:
- Approved for OSAP funding if applicant meets eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:

Context: Applicants are required to have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, a Grade 12 English credit (C or U), or mature student status (19 years of age or older and no OSSD) for admission to George Brown College. Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to achieve the required English credit. Course exemptions can be granted based on college or university credits, and international students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements. Students should be aware of potential allergens used in practical labs and that while products meet provincial and federal regulations, they may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, and international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. For admission-related inquiries, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage. Financial aid inquiries can be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or their webpage. For Baking and Pastry Foundations (H128) inquiries, contact CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca. George Brown College can be contacted through the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265. No explicit program information is provided in the text.

It also mentions various programs offered by the college related to baking and pastry arts, such as Baking and Pastry Arts Management (H113), Baker / Patissier Apprentice Program (H600), and Advanced French Patisserie (Postgraduate) (H413). The text also encourages visitors to sign up for campus tours, information sessions, and to receive tailored resources for their application process. Contact information for international recruitment representatives is provided on the International Contact Us page.
